## App Description from Google Play

This is a fork of {% include walletLink.html wallet='android/zapsolutions.zap' verdict='true' %}

> BitBanana is a native android app for node operators focused on user experience and ease of use. While it is not a wallet on its own, BitBanana works like a remote control allowing you to use your node as a wallet wherever you go. The app is designed with an educational approach, providing the user with guidance on every aspect of node operation.

## Analysis

The user initializes by connecting to a bitcoin lightning node. Once connected to a node, features such as backup, restore and other wallet features such as send and receive are made available. 


## Procedure 

To reproduce BitBanana, we follow the instructions in this [page.](https://github.com/michaelWuensch/BitBanana/blob/master/docs/REPRODUCE.md)  

Note: Some dependencies may need to be downloaded and installed.

The apks that were compared were of the built apk and the apk provided in the GitHub release.

This is a [pastebin](https://pastebin.com/GJfwy9gi) of the entire diffoscope output.

Leo has this assessment:

> 1. APK signing block: one has a signature and the other does not - as expected
> 2. Apksigner provides further details. Official was signed using version 2 scheme. Built APK produced an error as it's not signed.
> 3. Zipinfo finds that the official is bigger than the built. No surprise as the former contains a signature.
>
> **Absent further diffs, the app was reproduced successfully**.

## Documentation for RB attempt 3 dated 2023-11-13

1. We first execute:

    `git clone https://github.com/michaelWuensch/BitBanana.git`

    ```
    Cloning into 'BitBanana'...
    remote: Enumerating objects: 12645, done.

    remote: Compressing objects: 100% (634/634), done.

    Receiving objects: 100% (12645/12645), 10.35 MiB | 2.48 MiB/s, done.
    Resolving deltas: 100% (8290/8290), done.

    ```

2. We then checkout to version 0.6.8

    `git checkout v0.6.8`

    ```

    Note: switching to 'v0.6.8'.

    You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
    changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this
    state without impacting any branches by switching back to a branch.

    If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
    do so (now or later) by using -c with the switch command. Example:

    git switch -c <new-branch-name>

    Or undo this operation with:

    git switch -

    Turn off this advice by setting config variable advice.detachedHead to false

    ```

3. We then run docker, but the PC we were building from did not have docker, so we installed docker prior. 

    `docker run --rm -v pwd:/project mingc/android-build-box:1.25.0 bash -c 'cd /project; ./gradlew assembleRelease'`

4. We then create a separate 'compare' folder to compare the built apk and the released official apk. We download the released apk found in github. 
5. We then copy the produced apk found in `./app/build/outputs/apk/release` to the compare/built folder. For this version, it is `bitbanana-0.6.8_50-release-unsigned.apk`. 
6. We move the downloaded and released apk found in Github to compare/official.
7. We cd into the compare folder. 
8. Run `$ unzip -qqd fromBuild built/*.apk` 
9. Run `$ unzip -qqd fromOfficial official/*.apk`
10. Execute `$ diff --recursive from*`
11. There was no output if we would not copy output-metadata.json into the fromBuild folder. 
12. We then run `$ diffoscope built/ official/`, which results in:

13. We then analyze this using ChatGPT4: 
    - The two apks are differently-named: `bitbanana-0.6.8_50-release-unsigned.apk` and `bitbanana-0.6.8_50-release.apk`. It was noted that the built version also had an extra file with it namely, `output-metadata.json`
    - A significant difference was seen between the signing blocks since one of the apks is unsigned.
    - There is a slight difference in the file-sizes which may be due to the difference between one of the apks being unsigned, different build environments, or the inclusion/exclusion of some resources or metadata. The difference is 12,288 bytes or 12kb. Again, this difference was noted as benign. 
    - There is an error in APK verification which can be attributed to one of the apks being unsigned.
    - Other than these differences, most of the files remain the same which GPT4 signifies that the two apks are very likely to perform similarly.
    - There are also timestamp differences, indicating the difference when the apks were built.

Echoing our previous attempts, most of the differences are benign enough to mark this app as reproducible. We welcome feedback from other contributors to reproduce or corroborate our claims.
